data.text: The Earth in space
The Earth is spherical in shape and flattened at the North Pole and South Pole.
The Earth is tilted at 23.5° on its axis.
The axis is an imaginary line running from the North Pole to the South Pole through the centre of the Earth.
The Earth rotates, from west to east, on its axis.
The Earth takes 24 hours to complete one rotation.
The equator is an imaginary line that runs all the way around the middle of the Earth.
The equator divides the Earth into two equal halves—the northern hemisphere and the southern hemisphere.
The movement of the Earth around the Sun is called its revolution. The Earth takes one year to revolve around the Sun.
Causes of seasons:
Revolution of the Earth around the Sun
Tilt of the Earth's axis
The Moon is the Earth's natural satellite. It revolves around the Earth.
21 June is the longest day of the year and is known as the summer solstice.
22 December is the shortest day of the year and known as the winter solstice.
On 21 March, the day and night are of equal length. It is known as the spring equinox.
On 23 September, once again the day and night become equal in length. It is known as the autumn equinox.
